body: Close it because of invalid [issue-4801](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-4801).
LGTM
Remove the "." in the commit log please.

Thanks @vlsi, that resolved it. Just needed annotationProcessor, ~~not testAnnotationProcessor~~.

Scratch that, testAnnotationProcessor is also required.
Closing this PR. raised- https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/2551 with resolved rebase conflicts.

Hey @vlsi, I've pulled out use of immutables in test for this first patch. It's already pretty large. I also cleaned up the gradle stuff. LMK if you think it looks good to merge. Can do a test patch as follow-up.
@vlsi , updated to change condition of task. It seems to work the same in both cases (original and new condition) but I'm happy changing it.

Hi @hsyuan 
Could I take your time to review this issue and pr?
Thanks a lot.
Just in case, I've logged :server:test failure as https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-4824
Included this change in the original patch set via force push. Abandoning.
@vlsi, would love your help on this. I'd like to avoid having to duplicate the afterSync stuff in each subproject but don't know enough gradle/kotlin to figure this out.

Thank you for looking into this, however, I would like to refrain from making the change now.
Currently, the task definition and configuration are co-located, so they are easier to discover and understand. If you move a half of the configuration to a different file, then it becomes harder to reason about.

I'm going to merge Gradle 7.2 migration soon, and then we'll be able to use https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/structuring_software_products.html approach, so virtually all the code from the root file would be split across feature plugins.
It is going to fixed in the next kotlin-gradle-plugin version: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-47853

LGTM
@xuyangzhong the PR looks in a good shape, could you please squash commits into a single one so that we can merge it shortly?
Got it, thanks for the help. I'll use the workaround for now.
Abandoning for now.
Will replace with another PR.

It looks there are lots of commits from other fork...
It would be great if you rebase your changes and leave here only those which are related to the current issue

> @birschick-bq when the method argument does not have an explicit annotation then CheckerFramework uses a default based on some [rules](https://checkerframework.org/manual/#climb-to-top) and in the case of `getDefaultCompilerFactory` it is `@NonNull`. Moverover looking into the source code of `getDefaultCompilerFactory` it seems that if `null` is given as an input it will fail with NPE.
> 
> Regarding the `setParentClassLoader` method the `@Nullable` annotations used by Janino are not the same used with those used by the CheckerFramework. To align them we make use of `.astub` files.
> 
> I resolved the problems in commit [a0ef603](https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/a0ef603257c274d445a0c1b117db8b1eb595ca5a). Please have a look and let me know what you think. If all is good I will rebase and commit afterwards.

@zabetak Looks good to me. Thanks for resolving this issue. I was not familiar with how CheckerFramework works, in this situation.
@xy2953396112 please let me know if you would like to see anything else for a merge approval :)

Hi @yanlin-Lynn @xiayutianwei1994 @hsyuan 
Please review this pr, if you have a time.
If pr is ok, please ping me to rebase master.
LGTM~
@danny0405, @kgyrtkirk, @chunweilei, @rubenada, could you have a look at this PR?

LGTM~
Should we merge with another larger PR?

@xy2953396112 
We do allow "small contributions" to go in individually and no JIRA is required. The committer who gets this in should ensure the commit message is appropriate. See discussion in: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/3be39a8f4ba6adce91d9bed38ff988bb28d94fbbb799cb318d20c30d%40%3Cdev.calcite.apache.org%3E

@akashshukla-dm , please re-target PR. It looks like you did not intend to submit the PR to Calcite
@jacques-n Can you help review and approve this PR? Thanks!
Agree with @zabetak
looks good.
LGTM, nicely scoped.
looks good overall, thanks for the good work.

a little confused, from the jira discussion it seems a bug with converting sql identifier to values in the IN clause bracket. (I agree the title should be changed). but the fix seems only involving the config value change.

> a little confused, from the jira discussion it seems a bug with converting sql identifier to values in the IN clause bracket. (I agree the title should be changed). but the fix seems only involving the config value change.

This PR is not ready for review. The fix did not cover all unit tests. So I changed this PR to draft and plan to make some improvements.

If I understand @julianhyde 's comment correctly in the jira, the weirdness here is that you're saying this is a numeric but then numeric (a non-declared scale/precision decimal) doesn't exist in Calcite. If this is getting coerced into a decimal type (with declared scale/precision), it isn't clear to me how this is happening and where you test cases check for this. Unless I'm misunderstanding, it seems like you either need to:
- annotate the header with a specific scale/precision in the csv (e.g. `DECIMAL(30,2)`)
- choose a standard scale/precision irrespective of the data and truncate or throw when the data is outside that range. 
- pre-scan all the values to come up with a sufficient scale/precision to support the values in the csv you are reading.

Right now, it isn't clear to me what specifically is happening (and I'm not following how your test cases would clarify it).

That being said, I haven't gone back and reviewed the intricacies of Calcite and SQL Decimals so I may be missing something...
Resolved conflicts with current master
By the way. The commit info should be same as CALCITE-4768 in Jira.

> By the way. The commit info should be same as [CALCITE-4768](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-4768) in Jira.

Yes, you are right, I generally have the first commit already formatted like that, but I wanted to keep the commit messages meaningful with the actual changes and fix the commit message during the final squash. If you prefer I can amend it right away.
closed in favor of #2552

@thomasrebele Thanks a lot for taking care of the changes from #2486. I've closed that PR in favor of this PR. Everything looks good. 

Also for the sake of the compeleteness of this PR, maybe its easier to just copy paste the PR description from #2486 to here, so people don't have to jump to the old PR to see the images.
Maybe need to add another SQL type test in function.iq.

Thank you both for the review, I have squashed the commits and updated the commit message, once the test are over (even though there are no code changes since last run and the only commit missing from master was a site update) I think it can be merged.

On a second thought, there are some important info in the PR description that I think should be in the git description as well, could you add it when merging the PR?

Here is what I think could be added, feel free to rephrase it if needed:

```
* Updated Cassandra from 3.11.2 to 4.0.1
* Updated Datastax Driver from 3.6.0 to 4.13.0
* Updated cassandra-unit from 3.5.0.1 to 4.3.1.0
* Cassandra tests are:
 - now compatible with Guava >= 25 but are not anymore compatible with Guava < 20
 - still incompatible with Eclipse OpenJ9 (due to Cassandra)
 - still incompatible with JDK11+ (due to cassandra-unit)
```
Never mind, I have added the description because there was a conflict to fix with master (gradle.properties).

@jaystarshot  Can you add describe this plan in the Jira. (Before this PR and After) This can help other contributer understand what you resolve quickly.
@NobiGo Done

Yes, unfortunately Looker makes liberal use of `UNKNOWN`-typed expressions to represent arbitrary user-provided snippets of SQL. With a recent change making use of new rewrite rules, we ran into the issue of `UNKNOWN` types changing to `NULL` types when calling `createWithNullability`, and the rewrite rules failing.
@NobiGo @chunweilei  Can we merge this PR?
The `FAILURE   0.6sec, org.apache.calcite.test.ServerQuidemTest > test(String)[3], [3] sql/schema.iq` will be fixed here: https://github.com/apache/calcite-avatica/pull/161

> @NobiGo @chunweilei  Can we merge this PR?

After @chunweilei review, then we can merge it.

That is interesting. Tests with "avatica master branch" would fail since now it throws newer exceptions. On the other hand, if we merge this PR, then tests with the released avatica would fail.

It looks like we should postpone this PR till Avatica is released, and in the mean time we should use a fixed git commit (the one before the updated exceptions) for testing "avatica + calcite" integration.

> That is interesting. Tests with "avatica master branch" would fail since now it throws newer exceptions. On the other hand, if we merge this PR, then tests with the released avatica would fail.
> 
> It looks like we should postpone this PR till Avatica is released, and in the mean time we should use a fixed git commit (the one before the updated exceptions) for testing "avatica + calcite" integration.

Yes. I have noticed this too. It is unreasonable that test Calcite's master branch with Avatica's master branch directly. I support use a fixed git commit (the one before the updated exceptions) for testing "avatica + calcite" integration.

Thanks for the comments @vlsi and @NobiGo , If I understand correctly, we can make the 'calcite-avatica' version used in the test consistent with the property of 'calcite.avatica.version' configured in 'gradle.properties'. What do you think?
Will improve the job name after the test check success.

There's no point in having a separate job if "released" avatica version is used.

The test with "latest avatica" enables to uncover bugs if new commits to calcite accidentally call APIs that are removed in the recent Avatica commts.

This is the first time we have had an intended failure like that, and what do you think of a temporary disabling `Avatica master+current Calcite` job? As Avatica is released, we could re-enable the check.

Another option is to ask @julianhyde or someone who knows Quidem the way to handle the case in `.iq` test somehow (e.g. use different assertions for different avatica versions). I do not know what is the way to make `.iq` conditional on Avatica version.

I'm inclined we should solve this at `.iq` level or rewrite `.iq` test to regular JUnit, so can support multiple Avatica versions (e.g. via "contains message1 or message2").

Otherwise, it would be the case we support one specific Avatica version only, which questions the split of Calcite and Avatica into different repositories. So we either support at least two Avatica versions, or we should just merge the repositories and stop pretending they are independent libraries.

Simplest thing is to just support one version of Avatica in Calcite. Which is what we do already. 

Temporarily turn off the Avatica CI job that runs against Calcite latest. That job is a useful “early warning” but it’s fine if it doesn’t always work. 

Julian

> 
> Otherwise, it would be the case we support one specific Avatica version only, which questions the split of Calcite and Avatica into different repositories. So we either support at least two Avatica versions, or we should just merge the repositories and stop pretending they are independent libraries.

> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android.

> Simplest thing is to just support one version of Avatica in Calcite. Which is what we do already.

Should we merge the repositories then? Do we really gain much by splitting Avatica to a different repository?
Frankly speaking, it is harder to maintain when the repositories are separated: e.g. bump versions everywhere, bump Gradle, we have to vote twice, and so on.

> Should we merge the repositories then? 

In my opinion, no. And in any case, it's orthogonal to this case, so if feel strongly, start a DISCUSS email thread.

@vlsi I'm trying to fix this by adding a conditional into server.iq.

But as usual, defeated by Gradle:
```
Execution failed for task ':linq4j:compileJava'.
> Could not resolve all files for configuration ':linq4j:compileClasspath'.
   > Could not find org.apache.calcite.avatica:avatica-core:1.20.0-SNAPSHOT.
     Searched in the following locations:
       - https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/org/apache/calcite/avatica/avatica-core/1.20.0-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml
       - https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/org/apache/calcite/avatica/avatica-core/1.20.0-SNAPSHOT/avatica-core-1.20.0-SNAPSHOT.pom
     Required by:
         project :linq4j
   > Could not find org.apache.calcite.avatica:avatica-core:1.20.0-SNAPSHOT.
```
Avatica 1.20.0-SNAPSHOT exists. It is in .m2/repository. Gradle can't find it.

Sorry for the late reply.  @vlsi @julianhyde 

> Temporarily turn off the Avatica CI job that runs against Calcite latest. That job is a useful “early warning” but it’s fine if it doesn’t always work.

+1 for turn off the related tests, or temporarily delete problematic test for solve the  calcite-avatica and calcite builds.

Of course, we can fix the issue by adding a conditional. but I feel a little strange that the tests of the two projects depend on each other's master.  Can we permanently eliminate the testing dependence on master？

I have disabled Avatica running against Calcite master in https://github.com/apache/calcite-avatica/commit/4cf769f8ee32bb3520604e4f3284e6f233f90276. We can re-enable when the problem is fixed in Calcite master.

> @vlsi I'm trying to fix this by adding a conditional into server.iq.

Are you mean that we should change the `schema.iq` ?

I mean that someone should change `server.iq`. Add something like
```
!if (avaticaVersionGt1_19) {`
```
